Host.comment: This host is used in examples and template objects
Host.name: internal server

Host.comment: This host is used in examples and template objects
Host.name: server on dmz

Network.comment: 224.0.0.0/4 - This block, formerly known as the Class D address space, is allocated for use in IPv4 multicast address assignments. The IANA guidelines for assignments from this space are described in [RFC3171].
Network.name: all multicasts

Network.comment: 169.254.0.0/16 - This is the "link local" block. It is allocated for communication between hosts on a single link. Hosts obtain these addresses by auto-configuration, such as when a DHCP server may not be found.
Network.name: link-local

Network.comment: 127.0.0.0/8 - This block is assigned for use as the Internet host loopback address. A datagram sent by a higher level protocol to an address anywhere within this block should loop back inside the host. This is ordinarily implemented using only 127.0.0.1/32 for loopback, but no addresses within this block should ever appear on any network anywhere [RFC1700, page 5].
Network.name: loopback-net

Network.comment: 10.0.0.0/8 - This block is set aside for use in private networks. Its intended use is documented in [RFC1918]. Addresses within this block should not appear on the public Internet.
Network.name: net-10.0.0.0

Network.comment: 172.16.0.0/12 - This block is set aside for use in private networks. Its intended use is documented in [RFC1918]. Addresses within this block should not appear on the public Internet.
Network.name: net-172.16.0.0

Network.comment: 192.168.0.0/16 - This block is set aside for use in private networks. Its intended use is documented in [RFC1918]. Addresses within this block should not appear on the public Internet.
Network.name: net-192.168.0.0

Network.comment: 192.0.2.0/24 - This block is assigned as "TEST-NET" for use in documentation and example code. It is often used in conjunction with domain names example.com or example.net in vendor and protocol documentation. Addresses within this block should not appear on the public Internet.
Network.name: test-net

Network.comment: 0.0.0.0/8 - Addresses in this block refer to source hosts on "this" network. Address 0.0.0.0/32 may be used as a source address for this host on this network; other addresses within 0.0.0.0/8 may be used to refer to specified hosts on this network [RFC1700, page 4].
Network.name: this-net

Network.comment: 192.168.1.0/24 - Address often used for home and small office networks.
Network.name: net-192.168.1.0

Network.comment: 192.168.2.0/24 - Address often used for home and small office networks.
Network.name: net-192.168.2.0

CustomService.comment: This service matches all packets which are part of network connections established through the firewall, or connections 'related' to those established through the firewall. Term 'established' refers to the state tracking mechanism which exists inside iptables and other stateful firewalls and does not mean any particular combination of packet header options. Packet is considered to correspond to the state 'ESTABLISHED' if it belongs to the network session, for which proper initiation has been seen by the firewall, so its stateful inspection module made appropriate record in the state table. Usually stateful firewalls keep track of network connections using not only tcp protocol, but also udp and sometimes even icmp protocols. 'RELATED' describes packet belonging to a separate network connection, related to the session firewall is keeping track of. One example is FTP command and FTP data sessions.
CustomService.name: ESTABLISHED

ICMPService.comment: ICMP messages of this type are needed for traceroute
ICMPService.name: time exceeded

IPService.comment: All sorts of Source Routing Packets
IPService.name: SRR

IPService.comment: IPSEC Simple Key Management for Internet Protocols
IPService.name: SKIP

TCPService.comment: ipchains used to use this range of port numbers for masquerading.
TCPService.name: ALL TCP Masqueraded

TCPService.comment: Sometimes this protocol is called icslap, but Microsoft does not call it that and just says that DSPP uses port 2869 in Windows XP SP2
TCPService.name: icslap

TCPService.comment: data channel for PCAnywhere v7.52 and later
TCPService.name: PCAnywhere-data

TCPService.comment: FTP data channel. Note: FTP protocol does not really require server to use source port 20 for the data channel, but many ftp server implementations do so.
TCPService.name: ftp data

TCPService.comment: FTP data channel for passive mode transfers
TCPService.name: ftp data passive

TCPService.comment: Lightweight Directory Access Protocol over TLS/SSL
TCPService.name: ldaps

TCPService.comment: This service object matches TCP packet with all six flags set.
TCPService.name: xmas scan - full

TCPService.comment: This service object matches TCP packet with flags FIN, PSH and URG set and other flags cleared. This is a "christmas scan" as defined in snort rules. Nmap can generate this scan, too.
TCPService.name: xmas scan

TCPService.comment: Although UPnP specification say it should use TCP port 5000, Linksys running Sveasoft firmware listens on port 5431
TCPService.name: upnp-5431

TCPService.comment:
Some firewall platforms can match TCP packets with flags ACK or RST set; the option is usually called "established".
Note that you can use this object only in the policy rules of the firewall that supports this option.
If you need to match reply packets for a specific TCP service and wish to use option "established", make a copy of this object and set source port range to match the service.
TCPService.name: All TCP established

UDPService.comment: ipchains used to use this port range for masqueraded packets
UDPService.name: ALL UDP Masqueraded

UDPService.comment: status channel for PCAnywhere v7.52 and later
UDPService.name: PCAnywhere-status

UDPService.comment: Simple Service Discovery Protocol (used for UPnP)
UDPService.name: SSDP

CustomService.comment: works in iptables and requires patch-o-matic. For more information look for patch-o-matic on http://www.netfilter.org/
CustomService.name: rpc

CustomService.comment: IRC connection tracker, supports DCC. Works on iptables and requires patch-o-matic. For more information look for patch-o-matic on http://www.netfilter.org/
CustomService.name: irc-conn

CustomService.comment: Port scan detector, works only on iptables and requires patch-o-matic For more information look for patch-o-matic on http://www.netfilter.org/
CustomService.name: psd

CustomService.comment: Matches a string in a whole packet, works in iptables and requires patch-o-matic. For more information look for patch-o-matic on http://www.netfilter.org/
CustomService.name: string

CustomService.comment: Talk protocol support. Works in iptables and requires patch-o-matic. For more information look for patch-o-matic on http://www.netfilter.org/
CustomService.name: talk

Library.comment: Template objects that can be used to generate typical firewall configurations
Library.name: Firewall Templates

Host.comment: This object represents a PC with a single network interface
Host.name: PC with 1 interface

Host.comment: This object represents a PC with two network interfaces
Host.name: PC with 2 interfaces

Host.comment: This object represents a router with two interfaces. You may need to change interface names if your router uses different naming scheme.
Host.name: Router with 2 interfaces

Firewall.comment: This firewall has two interfaces. Eth0 faces outside and has a dynamic address; eth1 faces inside. Policy includes basic rules to permit unrestricted outbound access and anti-spoofing rules. Access to the firewall is permitted only from internal network and only using SSH. The firewall uses one of the machines on internal network for DNS. Internal network is configured with address 192.168.1.0/255.255.255.0
Firewall.name: fw template 1

PolicyRule.comment: anti spoofing rule
SSH Access to firewall is permitted only from internal network
Firewall uses one of the machines on internal network for DNS
All other attempts to connect to the firewall are denied and logged

Firewall.comment: Similar to fw 1, but the firewall is used as DHCP and DNS server for internal network. This firewall has two interfaces. Eth0 faces outside and has a dynamic address; eth1 faces inside. Policy includes basic rules to permit unrestricted outbound access and anti-spoofing rules. Access to the firewall is permitted only from internal network and only using SSH. The firewall can send DNS queries to servers out on the Internet. Another rule permits DNS queries from internal network to the firewall. Special rules permit DHCP requests from internal network and replies sent by the firewall.
Firewall.name: fw template 2

PolicyRule.comment: anti spoofing rule
SSH Access to firewall is permitted only from internal network Also firewall serves DNS for internal network
DHCP requests are permitted from internal network
DHCP replies
Firewall should be able to send DNS queries to the Internet
All other attempts to connect to the firewall are denied and logged

Firewall.comment: This firewall has three interfaces. Eth0 faces outside and has a static routable address; eth1 faces inside; eth2 is connected to DMZ subnet. Policy includes basic rules to permit unrestricted outbound access and anti-spoofing rules. Access to the firewall is permitted only from internal network and only using SSH. The firewall uses one of the machines on internal network for DNS. Internal network is configured with address 192.168.1.0/255.255.255.0, DMZ is 192.168.2.0/255.255.255.0. Since DMZ used private IP address, it needs NAT. There is a mail relay host located on DMZ (object 'server on dmz'). Policy rules permit SMTP connections to it from the Internet and allow this server to connect to a host on internal network 'internal server'. All other access from DMZ to internal net is denied. To provide access to the mail relay its private address is mapped to firewall's outside interface address by NAT rule #1.
Firewall.name: fw template 3

NATRule.comment: no need to translate between DMZ and internal net
Translate source address for outgoing connections

PolicyRule.comment: anti spoofing rule
SSH Access to firewall is permitted only from internal network
Firewall uses one of the machines on internal network for DNS
All other attempts to connect to the firewall are denied and logged
Quickly reject attempts to connect to ident server to avoid SMTP delays
Mail relay on DMZ can accept connections from hosts on the Internet
this rule permits a mail relay located on DMZ to connect to internal mail server
Mail relay needs DNS and can connect to mail servers on the Internet
All other access from DMZ to internal net is denied
This permits access from internal net to the Internet and DMZ

IPv4.comment: This is a test address, change it to your real one
IPv4.name: fw 3:eth0:ip

Firewall.comment: This is an example of a firewall protecting a host ( a server or a workstation). Only SSH access to the host is permitted. Host has dynamic address.
Firewall.name: host fw template 1

PolicyRule.comment: anti spoofing rule
SSH Access to the host; useful ICMP types; ping request

Firewall.comment:
This firewall is based on Linksys appliance running Sveasoft firmware; it has two interfaces. Interface vlan1 faces outside and has a dynamic address; br0 faces inside. Policy includes basic rules to permit unrestricted outbound access and anti-spoofing rules. Access to the firewall is permitted only from internal network and only using SSH or HTTP. The firewall uses name servers supplied by the ISP for DNS. Special rule blocks DHCP requests on external interface without logging to reduce noise in the log.
Internal network is configured with address 192.168.1.0/255.255.255.0
Firewall.name: linksys firewall

PolicyRule.comment: anti spoofing rule
SSH Access to firewall is permitted only from internal network
need this rule for ping and traceroute
All other attempts to connect to the firewall are denied and logged
server needs DNS to back-resolve clients IPs. Even if it does not log host names during its normal operations, statistics scripts such as webalizer need it for reporting.
this rule allows the server to send statistics and reports via email. Disable this rule if you do not need it.
this rejects auth (ident) queries that remote mail relays may send to this server when it tries to send email out.
anti-spoofing rule

IPv4.comment: Configure IP address and netmask for this interface
IPv4.name: c36xx:Ethernet1/1:ip

IPv4.comment: Configure IP address and netmask for this interface
IPv4.name: c36xx:Serial1/0:ip
